item.title: Cooktimer pi
item.dc:creator: @ohokay ohokay
item.description:
@ohokay wrote:

That’s where you need to give your timer a value, the higher the number, the longer it will wait. Then you need to use if statements to check whether the timer is at 0 so the cooking can continue.

item.title: Cooktimer pi
item.dc:creator: @Nebulae Nebulae
item.description:
@Nebulae wrote:

Graham’s event manager should be in PI, use it. If not, rip the folder from Hyperion and fix the imports. You won’t have loads of processes running every half a second then, they will run in a different thread. This is why PI is shit and so unstable.

Read full topic

item.title: Cooktimer pi
item.dc:creator: @ohokay ohokay
item.description:
@ohokay wrote:

If you took 5 seconds to read what I said, I’m pretty sure anyone with a brain could understand what I meant.

Here’s a basic timer used with the walking method to demonstrate how they work.

public int disablemovement;

This needs to be given a value somewhere.

if (disablemovement > 0) { //This should be under process
disablemovement--;
}

Why process? I believe it’s called every 500ms, so it will constantly check to see if this variable is above 0. If it is, it will reduce it until it’s at 0.

Now find the walking method

		if(c.disablemovement > 0 && packetType != 98) {
                        c.sendMessage("You're movement is disabled");
			c.playerIndex = 0;
			return;
		}

Checks if the value is above 0, if it is, you can’t walk until the value reaches 0 again. It’s that simple.

So all you need to do is change that to work with your cooking method. When it starts to cook, set a small timer before it moves on to the next item. Use if statements to check whether the timer has reached 0 or not.

Read full topic

item.title: Cooktimer pi
item.dc:creator: @nerd123456789 ...nerd123456789
item.description:
@nerd123456789 wrote:

ok so i’m trying to add a timer when i cook so it doesn’t instantly cook
so i was looking trough other skills and i found this in the fishing class:

 public void FishingProcess() {
        if (c.fishtimer > 0) {
            c.fishtimer--;
        }

i tried changing it to this:

        public void CookingProcess() {
        if (c.cooktimer > 0) {
            c.cooktimer--;
        }
        }

this is the error i get:

src\server\model\players\skills\Cooking.java:29: error: cannot find symbol
        if (c.cooktimer > 0) {
             ^
  symbol:   variable cooktimer
  location: variable c of type Client
src\server\model\players\skills\Cooking.java:30: error: cannot find symbol
            c.cooktimer--;
             ^
  symbol:   variable cooktimer
  location: variable c of type Client
Note: Some input files use unchecked or unsafe operations.
Note: Recompile with -Xlint:unchecked for details.
2 errors

how can i make it work for cooking? (yes i know i have to declare cooktimer somewhere or something like that)

Read full topic
